awd_titl_txt: Meeting-The Morphological Diversity of Intromittent Organs, Society of Integrative and Comparative Biology: January 5th, 2016; Portland, Oregon
awd_abstract_narration:
The primary goal of this symposium will be to build a synthetic understanding of the factors that interact to make intromittent organs some of the most morphologically diverse structures in the animal kingdom. The symposium will attract researchers studying functional morphology, ecological morphology, behavior, and developmental biology in both vertebrate and invertebrate taxa. The symposium will improve and broaden this field of study by encouraging new collaborations between research groups that have not previously interacted and identifying conceptual similarities among the reproductive structures of diverse taxonomic groups. Further, a special conference-wide session about effectively communicating the value of basic and seemingly esoteric research efforts to a broader audience will also occur. 
 
This symposium will break down the walls that separate scientists studying different aspects of intromittent organs, integrating researchers studying functional morphology, ecological morphology, behavior, and developmental biology and who address these questions in both vertebrate and invertebrate taxa. The speakers will also highlight new studies and methods being used in the study of intromittent organs, including molecular and genomic techniques, macro- and micro-CT, finite element analysis, and 3D reconstruction of morphology. Thus, attendees will have the opportunity to learn new methodology and share expertise, and these interactions will lead to the creation of valuable and lasting collaborative bridges. Moreover, the volume of conference papers produced for a special issue of Integrative and Comparative Biology (ICB) will serve as a valuable resource for future researchers and lecturers.

por.por_cntn:
A species’ reproductive anatomy has profound impacts on how mates interact and how rivals compete for fertilization. Further, previous studies of copulation have changed long-held beliefs about the interactions between the sexes and added complexity to both reproductive biology and evolutionary theory. But, for many species little detailed information is known about male reproductive anatomy and how it functions during copulation. Therefore, in January 2016, National Science Foundation funding support enabled a first-of-its-kind, eleven-speaker conference symposium dedicated to exploring the comparative biology of male reproductive structures that transfer gametes into females: “The Morphological Diversity of Intromittent Organs”. The immediate symposium goals were:

  1. To build a greater synthetic understanding of the biological factors which interact to make intromittent organs some of the most morphologically diverse structures in the animal kingdom.
  2. To identify conceptual similarities among the reproductive structures of diverse taxonomic groups.
  3. To improve and broaden this field of study by encouraging new collaborations between research groups which have not previously interacted.

      To that end, the symposium worked to break down the walls that separated scientists studying different aspects of intromittent organs, to integrate researchers studying diverse features of intromittent organ functional morphology, ecological morphology, behavior, and developmental biology, and to connect those who address these questions in both vertebrate and invertebrate species. We succeeded in gathering a diverse group of women and men from all career stages (undergraduate trainees to full professors), including an international colleague (United Kingdom).  This sizable group left the symposium venue with new ideas and new collaborators to stimulate and advance the productivity of their individual lab groups. Finally, an eleven-manuscript volume of conference papers from the symposium was published in Integrative and Comparative Biology (October 2016) and will serve as a valuable resource for future researchers and education lecturers.
